title: How to Make a Checkbook Wallet

steps.headline: Obtain the items listed in the "Things  You'll Need" section below.
steps.description: Launder all fabrics and press them smooth.

steps.headline: A checkbook type wallet needs a cover that is a square 8 inches (20cm) on a side.
steps.description: Cut the outer fabric to this size. You may add a bit of width to this measurement to give yourself some leeway while sewing, but be prepared to cut off the extra before you add the bias tape to finish the edges.

steps.headline: Cut a 9 x 20 inch (22.8cm x 50.8cm) fabric swatch for the credit card pockets and take it to your ironing board with some pins and a ruler or measuring tape.
steps.description:
Note: this can be 8 x 20, but it doesn't hurt to have a bit extra width to help match fabric pattern, etc. See the sketch. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Wallet-sketch.jpg\/460px-Wallet-sketch.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Wallet-sketch.jpg\/728px-Wallet-sketch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"548","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Iron a crease every 4 inches (10cm).
Iron five 2 inch (5cm) by 8 inch (20cm) wide strips of interfacing to the back side of the fabric, lined up with each pleat.
Top stitch the pleats and then align them in a stair step fashion (approx 1/4 inch / 6.35mm apart).
steps.description: Iron again to crease the pocket bottoms into place.

steps.headline: Stitch a line up the center of your pocket pleats if you are going to have two columns of cards side by side.
steps.description: (This is recommended for this size wallet).

steps.headline: Create a zipper pocket for your coins.
steps.description: Cut two strips of fabric 9 inches (22.8cm) long (the width of the wallet) and at least 6 inches (15cm) tall.

steps.headline: Line up one edge of the zipper along the top edge of your CC pockets.

Position the contrast fabric and the top of the CC pouch fabric with their 9 inch (22.8cm) edges along the zipper and sew them to each side of the zipper starting at the opening end (not the closed end of the zipper).
steps.description: An easy way to do this is to purchase a 9 inch (22.8cm) zipper to begin with, but you may also shorten a longer zipper if you need to.

steps.headline: Fold the fabric away from the zipper teeth and top stitch the fabric so that it does not "catch" in the zipper teeth later.
Top stitch.
Repeat for both sides.
steps.description: You may sew a second piece of fabric to the reverse side of the zipper at the same time if you wish to make a lined coin pocket. (Nice? But not necessary.)

steps.headline: Close the zipper and flatten the fabric.
steps.description: Fold the fabric over so that the zipper is positioned along the top front edge. Pin the sides and baste them together.

steps.headline: Trim any extra length at the bottom of the coin pocket at this point.
steps.description: Don't worry about basting it. This will be fastened closed in the final step.

steps.headline: Lay the credit card pocket with its zipper over the outer/inner layer sandwich.
steps.description: Line up the edges so that the zipper is in the center, along the fold line. Pin.

steps.headline: Create a pocket for the other side.
steps.description: Cut a 9 x 8 inch (22.8cm x 20cm) piece of fabric. Iron interfacing to the back of it. Fold in half. Baste the short edges. Top stitch the long folded edge.

steps.headline: Place the wallet exterior and liner back to back and line up the edges.
Place the coin pocket/CC pockets with zippered edge to the center and raw edges to the outside edge.
Place the pocket along the opposite edge, with raw edges to the outside and the finished edge along the center folding line of the wallet.
Pin and then machine baste all layers together.
steps.description: Trim any threads or uneven edges.

steps.headline: Pin the bias tape to the edges.
Top stitch the bias tape into place, taking care to catch all layers in the stitching.
steps.description: Double stitch for security if you feel it necessary.

steps.headline: Trim all loose threads.

tyn: Approximately 1/4 yard (22.86cm) each of the following fabrics: Heavy denim or twill for the exterior and two contrasting fabrics for your lining
Sewing machine (optional? But this will be
easier to do on a machine)
Measuring tape and possibly a square edge
A few credit cards (for measuring purposes)
text:
Obtain the items listed in the "Things You'll Need" section below. Launder all fabrics and press them smooth. A checkbook type wallet needs a cover that is a square 8 inches (20cm) on a side. Cut the outer fabric to this size. You may add a bit of width to this measurement to give yourself some leeway while sewing, but be prepared to cut off the extra before you add the bias tape to finish the edges. Cut a 9 x 20 inch (22.8cm x 50.8cm) fabric swatch for the credit card pockets and take it to your ironing board with some pins and a ruler or measuring tape. Note: this can be 8 x 20, but it doesn't hurt to have a bit extra width to help match fabric pattern, etc. See the sketch. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Wallet-sketch.jpg\/460px-Wallet-sketch.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Wallet-sketch.jpg\/728px-Wallet-sketch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"548","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Iron a crease every 4 inches (10cm). Iron five 2 inch (5cm) by 8 inch (20cm) wide strips of interfacing to the back side of the fabric, lined up with each pleat. Top stitch the pleats and then align them in a stair step fashion (approx 1/4 inch / 6.35mm apart). Iron again to crease the pocket bottoms into place. Stitch a line up the center of your pocket pleats if you are going to have two columns of cards side by side. (This is recommended for this size wallet). Create a zipper pocket for your coins. Cut two strips of fabric 9 inches (22.8cm) long (the width of the wallet) and at least 6 inches (15cm) tall. Line up one edge of the zipper along the top edge of your CC pockets. Pin. Position the contrast fabric and the top of the CC pouch fabric with their 9 inch (22.8cm) edges along the zipper and sew them to each side of the zipper starting at the opening end (not the closed end of the zipper). An easy way to do this is to purchase a 9 inch (22.8cm) zipper to begin with, but you may also shorten a longer zipper if you need to. Fold the fabric away from the zipper teeth and top stitch the fabric so that it does not "catch" in the zipper teeth later. Top stitch. Repeat for both sides. You may sew a second piece of fabric to the reverse side of the zipper at the same time if you wish to make a lined coin pocket. (Nice? But not necessary.) Close the zipper and flatten the fabric. Fold the fabric over so that the zipper is positioned along the top front edge. Pin the sides and baste them together. Trim any extra length at the bottom of the coin pocket at this point. Don't worry about basting it. This will be fastened closed in the final step. Lay the credit card pocket with its zipper over the outer/inner layer sandwich. Line up the edges so that the zipper is in the center, along the fold line. Pin. Create a pocket for the other side. Cut a 9 x 8 inch (22.8cm x 20cm) piece of fabric. Iron interfacing to the back of it. Fold in half. Baste the short edges. Top stitch the long folded edge. Place the wallet exterior and liner back to back and line up the edges. Pin. Place the coin pocket/CC pockets with zippered edge to the center and raw edges to the outside edge. Pin. Place the pocket along the opposite edge, with raw edges to the outside and the finished edge along the center folding line of the wallet. Pin and then machine baste all layers together. Trim any threads or uneven edges. Pin the bias tape to the edges. Top stitch the bias tape into place, taking care to catch all layers in the stitching. Double stitch for security if you feel it necessary. Trim all loose threads. Enjoy your wallet!
sentences: Obtain the items listed in the "Things  You'll Need" section below.
Launder all fabrics and press them smooth.
A checkbook type wallet needs a cover that is a square 8 inches (20cm) on a side.
Cut the outer fabric to this size.
You may add a bit of width to this measurement to give yourself some leeway while sewing, but be prepared to cut off the extra before you add the bias tape to finish the edges.
Cut a 9 x 20 inch (22.8cm x 50.8cm) fabric swatch for the credit card pockets and take it to your ironing board with some pins and a ruler or measuring tape.
Note: this can be 8 x 20, but it doesn't hurt to have a bit extra width to help match fabric pattern, etc.
See the sketch.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Wallet-sketch.jpg\/460px-Wallet-sketch.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Wallet-sketch.jpg\/728px-Wallet-sketch.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"548","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Iron a crease every 4 inches (10cm).
Iron five 2 inch (5cm) by 8 inch (20cm) wide strips of interfacing to the back side of the fabric, lined up with each pleat.
Top stitch the pleats and then align them in a stair step fashion (approx 1/4 inch / 6.35mm apart).
Iron again to crease the pocket bottoms into place.
Stitch a line up the center of your pocket pleats if you are going to have two columns of cards side by side.
(This is recommended for this size wallet).
Create a zipper pocket for your coins.
Cut two strips of fabric 9 inches (22.8cm) long (the width of the wallet) and at least 6 inches (15cm) tall.
Line up one edge of the zipper along the top edge of your CC pockets.
Pin.

Position the contrast fabric and the top of the CC pouch fabric with their 9 inch (22.8cm) edges along the zipper and sew them to each side of the zipper starting at the opening end (not the closed end of the zipper).
An easy way to do this is to purchase a 9 inch (22.8cm) zipper to begin with, but you may also shorten a longer zipper if you need to.
Fold the fabric away from the zipper teeth and top stitch the fabric so that it does not "catch" in the zipper teeth later.
Top stitch.
Repeat for both sides.
You may sew a second piece of fabric to the reverse side of the zipper at the same time if you wish to make a lined coin pocket.
(Nice?
But not necessary.)
Close the zipper and flatten the fabric.
Fold the fabric over so that the zipper is positioned along the top front edge.
Pin the sides and baste them together.
Trim any extra length at the bottom of the coin pocket at this point.
Don't worry about basting it.
This will be fastened closed in the final step.
Lay the credit card pocket with its zipper over the outer/inner layer sandwich.
Line up the edges so that the zipper is in the center, along the fold line.
Pin.
Create a pocket for the other side.
Cut a 9 x 8 inch (22.8cm x 20cm) piece of fabric.
Iron interfacing to the back of it.
Fold in half.
Baste the short edges.
Top stitch the long folded edge.
Place the wallet exterior and liner back to back and line up the edges.
Pin.
Place the coin pocket/CC pockets with zippered edge to the center and raw edges to the outside edge.
Pin.
Place the pocket along the opposite edge, with raw edges to the outside and the finished edge along the center folding line of the wallet.
Pin and then machine baste all layers together.
Trim any threads or uneven edges.
Pin the bias tape to the edges.
Top stitch the bias tape into place, taking care to catch all layers in the stitching.
Double stitch for security if you feel it necessary.
Trim all loose threads.
Enjoy your wallet!
